articles.headline: In Price of Farmland, Echoes of Another Boom
articles.snippet: Regulators are warning that a new real estate bubble may be forming as farmland prices surge across the Midwest.
articles.abstract: Regulators are warning that a new real estate bubble may be forming as farmland prices surge across the Midwest.
articles.lead_paragraph: The 80 acres of rich farmland that Jeff Freking and his brother Randy bought near Le Mars, Iowa, on Monday for $10,000 an acre would seem to have nothing in common with a condo in Miami or a house in Las Vegas.

articles.headline: Libya’s Hidden Wealth May Be Next Battle
articles.snippet: The country’s sovereign wealth fund has $70 billion in assets but much of it is invested in Libya or the Middle East, out of the reach of sanctions.
articles.abstract: The country’s sovereign wealth fund has $70 billion in assets but much of it is invested in Libya or the Middle East, out of the reach of sanctions.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  As the battle for Libya rages on, the struggle over control of the country’s sovereign wealth fund and its $70 billion in assets has just begun.

articles.headline: For Boards, S.E.C. Keeps the Bar Low
articles.snippet: If the S.E.C. can’t prove that directors took part in fraud, they almost always escape with no penalty beyond a tarnished reputation. So much for the goals of Sarbanes-Oxley.
articles.abstract: If the S.E.C. can’t prove that directors took part in fraud, they almost always escape with no penalty beyond a tarnished reputation. So much for the goals of Sarbanes-Oxley.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a vast accounting fraud is disclosed, or when a chief executive is caught looting a company, it is to be expected that the Securities and Exchange Commission will bring civil charges against the responsible executives. In egregious cases, criminal prosecution may follow.

articles.headline: In Colombia, New Gold Rush Fuels Old Conflict
articles.snippet: Seizing on the surge in gold prices, combatants from multiple sides of the conflict in Colombia are shifting into gold mining.
articles.abstract: Seizing on the surge in gold prices, combatants from multiple sides of the conflict in Colombia are shifting into gold mining.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAUCASIA, Colombia  Officers pored over intelligence reports describing the movements of two warlords with private armies. Then the helicopters lifted off at dawn, carrying an elite squad armed with assault rifles to the newest front in this country’s long war: gold mines.

articles.headline: Calls Mount to Tap U.S. Oil Reserves
articles.snippet: The administration says that excess production capacity is well above what has been disrupted by unrest in the Middle East.
articles.abstract: The administration says that excess production capacity is well above what has been disrupted by unrest in the Middle East.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As oil prices have risen in recent weeks, calls have been growing in Congress for the Obama administration to consider tapping into the nation’s strategic petroleum reserve, which is now at its full capacity of 727 million barrels.
articles.byline: By John M. Broder and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Pharmacists Fight the Rise of Mail Order
articles.snippet: Drug chains and mom-and-pop pharmacies argue they are better able to manage a patient’s medications and contend that health plans should allow the option of buying medicine at their stores.
articles.abstract: Drug chains and mom-and-pop pharmacies argue they are better able to manage a patient’s medications and contend that health plans should allow the option of buying medicine at their stores.
articles.lead_paragraph: A fierce battle is being waged between retail pharmacists and mail-order companies over where people should be able to fill their long-term prescriptions.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Natasha Singer

articles.headline: A Tasty Fungus, Stirring Dreams and Lawsuits
articles.snippet: At $800 a pound for some types, truffles have some people in North Carolina excited. They also have two growers suing.
articles.abstract: At $800 a pound for some types, truffles have some people in North Carolina excited. They also have two growers suing.
articles.lead_paragraph: HILLSBOROUGH, N.C. — The two contenders in the great North Carolina truffle wars could not be more different.

articles.headline: Without Loan Giants, 30-Year Mortgage May Fade Away
articles.snippet: If Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac shut down, interest rates would rise for most borrowers, but urban and rural residents could see sharper increases than customers in the suburbs.
articles.abstract: If Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac shut down, interest rates would rise for most borrowers, but urban and rural residents could see sharper increases than customers in the suburbs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — How might home buying change if the federal government shuts down the housing finance giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac?

articles.headline: Experts Fear Looted Libyan Arms May Find Way to Terrorists
articles.snippet: Past examples of state arsenals being looted by civilians have shown that once these weapons slip from state custody they can be sold through black markets, swiftly and quietly.
articles.abstract: Past examples of state arsenals being looted by civilians have shown that once these weapons slip from state custody they can be sold through black markets, swiftly and quietly.
articles.lead_paragraph: Security analysts say the armed uprising in Libya poses a long-term security threat  that weapons looted from government stockpiles could circulate widely, including heat-seeking antiaircraft missiles that could be used against civilian airliners.

articles.headline: Qaddafi Brutalizes Foes, Armed or Defenseless
articles.snippet: The actions of Qaddafi’s militia are likely to stir debate over international intervention to limit his use of military power against his citizens.
articles.abstract: The actions of Qaddafi’s militia are likely to stir debate over international intervention to limit his use of military power against his citizens.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya  Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi counterattacked with brutal force on Friday, battling rebel forces on two fronts, firing on unarmed protesters in front of international news media and leaving the rebels seeking his ouster in disarray.

articles.headline: Big Jump in Private Jobs Bolsters Recovery Hopes
articles.snippet: The U.S. economy added 192,000 jobs in February, in line with expectations, the fastest job growth since last spring. The rate of unemployment ticked down to 8.9 percent.
articles.abstract: The U.S. economy added 192,000 jobs in February, in line with expectations, the fastest job growth since last spring. The rate of unemployment ticked down to 8.9 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: The economic waiting game may soon be over, as businesses signal that they are finally willing to resume widespread hiring.

articles.headline: In Philadelphia, New Cases Loom in Priest Scandal
articles.snippet: Dozens of priests accused of sexual abuse remain in their parishes, weeks after a report criticizing the Archdiocese.
articles.abstract: Dozens of priests accused of sexual abuse remain in their parishes, weeks after a report criticizing the Archdiocese.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA  Three weeks after a scathing grand jury report said the Archdiocese of Philadelphia had provided safe haven to as many as 37 priests who were credibly accused of sexual abuse or inappropriate behavior toward minors, most of those priests remain active in the ministry.
